user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarWait:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarWait(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarWait_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarWait:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR 0x0D
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_CondVarWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
     * note that because pthread_cond_wait is a cancellation point, this needs to
     * employ the same protection that is in the binsem module.  In the event that
     * the thread is canceled inside pthread_cond_wait, the mutex will be re-acquired
     * before the cancellation occurs, leaving the mutex in a locked state.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_wait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler language extensions as described by MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2. Specifically:

- There are no compiler-specific keywords or builtins present (e.g. __attribute__, __extension__, __builtin_*, asm, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) or GCC/Clang-specific extensions).
- The pthread_cleanup_push / pthread_cleanup_pop usage is a POSIX threads API macro pair (library-level), not a compiler language extension; their use is an API facility rather than a compiler-specific language extension. Any internal implementation details of these macros (in the C library) are outside the scope of this source and would need to be checked against the C library documentation if desired.
- typedefs (int32, osal_id_t), standard fixed-width integer types (int32_t/uint32_t), pointer-to-incomplete-type usage, macros like OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and constant macros (OS_SUCCESS, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR) are all standard C constructs or preprocessor artifacts, not compiler language extensions.
- No inline assembly, nonstandard linkage specifications, or other vendor-specific language features appear in the provided fragments.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for potential use of compiler language extensions.
